reviews.review_text: What is Hatoful Boyfriend? Hatoful Boyfriend is a bird dating sim.  I purchased this because I thought it would be funny to say that I was playing a bird dating sim. There wasn’t suppose to be any real feelings behind this purchase, it was all in jest.   I launched the game and quickly got to the bad ending. I figured I should at least complete one or two “good” endings before I uninstalled the game and abandoned it to be just another game in my library. To accomplish my goal of being able to complete a good ending, I quickly made a “birds.txt” where I would list everybody in the story with a couple words to allow me to remember who was who.  Ryouta : Childhood friend, sick Sakuya : ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Yuuya : Works in infirmiry, upperclassmen, half brother of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, flirt Nageki : Library silent dude San : RUN RUN RUN RUN RUN Kazuaki : Homeroom / math teacher, falls asleep Shuu : Doctor   Referencing this “cheat sheet”, I was able to get a good ending fairly easily. I repeated myself, this time going for a different ending...sometime in this third playthrough, something changed.  By the end of that ending, I was actually enjoying what I was doing. This “Joke of a game” was actually drawing me in, not because of “bird dating sim”, but because of the actual plot and the compelling characters. My cheat sheet was pointless, I knew all the names. Everybirdie had their own personality, and their stories had wildly different outcomes, yet were all tied together to help reveal a plot that actually mattered.   As you play through the game more, and achieve different endings you find little bits and pieces about the world. You read how birds became the dominant lifeform on the planet, how the human race almost fell to extinction, and how bird politics work.  Each story feel completely different. They all showcase a huge variety of emotions and social conditions. One story / ending exists entirely for humor, and no deep thought is put into anything. You are able to laugh your way through a 20 minute story and have a great time. You re-roll your game, and suddenly your story is filled with great sorrow between all the funny bird puns. Sadness then turns into happiness as your story becomes complete. Re-roll again, now you are exploring yet more bird puns, but this time also the impossible expectations sometimes forced onto oneself from their family. Re-roll, now genocide is brought into the fold. Re-roll, we are happy and excited again.  What the hell just happened? This game somehow managed to put an actual fantastic plot full of emotion and lessons of how the world works into...a bird dating simulator. Somehow this completely over the top game idea is completely overlooked the more you play it and fall in love with it.    Everybirdie should download this game and try it out because “lol bird dating sim”. You’ll be amazed as the joke suddenly starts being enjoyable and the fact that everyone is a bird spouting bird puns is able to be completely overlooked.  What is Hatoful Boyfriend? Hatoful Boyfriend is a fantastic game filled with more emotion and story than it should possibly contain.

I, uh, I c-can explain! J-just give me a sec; it's not what it looks like! I got the game for t-the, um, story! Just listen, I'm going somewhere with this okay? *sigh* Okay, without further ado, I present to you...  LASTING IMPRESSIONS Hatoful Boyfriend  GENRE Dating Simulator/Visual Novel  STORY In Hatoful Boyfriend you take the role of Hiyoko Tosaka, a human going to a prestigious highschool for birds. The school in question is St. Pigeonation’s, and it's known mostly for being the world's greatest gathering place for birds. You're a sophomore now, but you haven't done much to adjust to the atmosphere of Pigeonation's just yet. You're not entirely lost though, as you also have one of the several woo-able birds with you, your hardworking best friend Ryouta Kawara. Along with him you can also bond with narcoleptic math teacher Nanaki Kazuaki, bashful aristocrat Sakuya Le Bel Shirogane, distant bookworm Fujishiro Nageki, suave ladies' man Sakazaki Yuuya, enigmatic doctor Iwamine Shuu, and hyperactive track star Okosan. With so much romance in the air, it's hard to believe the school holds so many dark secrets...  GAMEPLAY Ever read a book online? It's like that except every once in a while the books asks which choice you want to make. The choices you make will determine which bird you end up with, along with which ending you get for them. [Provided you don't get indesicive and go the way of the dodo, of course.] Each day you will be asked which class you want to take; this decides which trait will be leveled for that day. As previously mentioned, this will affect which ending you get for your desired bird.  VISUALS Not much to say. It's pictures of birds with various backgrounds. The backgrounds look very nice, and there's quite a large amount of them. You also get a little end card pictures for your gallery after the end of each route. They're gosh darned cute.  SOUNDTRACK The soundtrack is a delightful mix of royalty-free, classics, and original [I think?] tracks. All of them fit perfectly with any of the situations at hand. [Except maybe when Dance of the Sugar Plum Fairy plays, that's always just plain silly.] There's many tracks from Kevin MacLoed and SENTIVE; the sexy, suave Dispersion Relation, Simply Blue, Daybreak [Personal favorite.], and tons of ones with gibberish for names. The collector's edition is worth is just for the beautiful OST.  SEQUELS [SPOILERS] Hatoful Boyfriend is the quintessential example of an idea that I've had for a while now; some games should never get sequels. While it's obvious that a bad game shouldn't deserve a sequel; I'm of the opinion that if a game is GOOD enough it shouldn't HAVE a sequel. If a game does all that it wishes, if a game provides a fulfilling, complete experience; it would be insulting to continue where the game left off. You may be thinking 'How does a game about dating birds provide a fulfilling experience?' I'll tell you; it's because the entire dating sim portion of the game is a mere facade. Once you've completed all possible routes at least once, you have the option to unlock BBL; a grim narrative that reveals the lore behind this game's world, the motivations and sins of characters, and completes all story arcs. The dating sim part of Hatoful Boyfriend is there simply to set up characters so that you know who this story is centered around. You know how they act by then, what their situations are, and this only helps to greatly strengthen the story. It's a fantastic conclusion, and it's one that left me speechless. Which brings us back to sequels. As I've said, a sequel to this game woud be a downright insult; a direct sequel that is. A direct sequel would be insulting, as the game would have nowhere to go with the current story; all arcs are completed. However, an indirect sequel would be a very, very smart idea if done correctly. By merely taking the characters we know and love and putting them in a different kind of story; the game has somewhere to go. Oh, and it did go somwhere, as an indirect sequel exists. [Holiday Star is its name if you were wondering. Not yet on steam though.]  FINAL THOUGHTS I dove this game. To say that this was a pheasant experience would be the understatement of the century. While at first glance, it may look like quite the bad egg, it's surely a narrative you'll never forget. I'm talon you, it's all here! Great soundtrack, amazing characters, bird puns; it's just a quail of a time! The price ain't nothin to go squawkin' about neither, no need to worry about some ludicrous bill. This is the defenition of the phrase 'more than meets the eye' and you'd have to be some hard boiled individual not to enjoy the humor at the least. I know I'm gushing, but I just can't recommend this enough! While you're at it, make sure to kill two birds with one stone and buy the collector's edition with it. The soundtrack alone makes it worth it. Alright, I've egged you on for far too much now, I'll sparrow you of any more. Hatoful Boyfriend has left a resounding lasting impression; it's not what the source material is, it's what you do with it that makes it a golden goose egg. You've got your ducks in a row MediaTonic, keep it up.  And now, in Japanese tradition, a haiku. Hatoful Boyfriend, A dating sim about birds. I was not prepared.

In Hatoful Boyfriend, you play as Hiyoko Tosaka (or whatever you choose to name her), the only human in a school of pigeons. You can even get yourself a birdy boyfriend! There's Ryouta the childhood friend, Sakuya the fancypants, Yuuya the ladies man, and many more amazing avians. It plays out like a regular otome/visual novel does, read the text and make some choices. I bet you're thinking 'omg so random, dating pigeons lol', and that's a natural response. But if you were to look up the definition of 'don't judge a book by its cover', I'm pretty sure there would be a picture of Hatoful Boyfriend there.  You see, the pigeon dating sim premise is just a cover for the real story. After you unlock certain endings with different birds, you can start a new game and the true story will reveal itself, aka the Hurtful Boyfriend (or Bad Boys Love) route. In BBL you will learn why Hiyoko is the only human at the pigeon school, why the pigeons can talk, why she needs to form a bond with the birds, and much more. I can only say so much without spoiling it, but be prepared for a mental meltdown. It is filled with drama, tragedy and unsettling content. After seeing certain endings in the dating sim part, you'll probably be thinking 'well, I've already seen some disturbing stuff... This will be a piece of cake'. LOL NOPE. The dating sim endings are nothing compared to the true BBL route.   To put it simply, this game is like one of those sweet & sour candies; it looks and tastes sweet on the outside, but once you delve deeper in you'll reel back in shock and wonder wtf happened to the sugary outer shell.

At first glance, Hatoful Boyfriend may appear to be a parody of the visual novel dating sim games which have gained popularity recently. And upon completing your first playthrough and finding a pigeon to be your soulmate, this would be an entirely accurate assumption to make. However, the real depth of this game surfaces with each continual playthrough. Something far more sinister is happening at St. Pigeonation's. You will eventually find out the answer to almost any question you may have had when you first heard of the game. Why is everyone a bird? Why are you a human? Who is the Hatoful Boyfriend? The path to this knowledge will take a lot of perseverance, but you will be surprised by the outcome.

Initially, Hatoful Boyfriend struck me as a purely comedic otome game. Like many who chose to play it, I decided to go through it for kicks. Eventually, I learned that it is not what it seems at all. The more I progressed through the game the more immersed I became in it. I forgot all about the fact that it was meant to be a dating simulator where you court birds. I learned that it possesses all the trappings of classic visual novels. It is rife with plot twists and angst. The story is surprisingly deep, something I found to be a relief. As you go through the routes you obtain more and more pieces of the proverbial puzzle. They fit together pretty nicely at the end. I was glad to know that it is more than just some silly thing.  Although it has many elements and troupes that are common in such games it presented them in a unique way, I think. However, my taste for it was admittedly acquired. After having went through a route in its entirety I became bored of many of the jokes and scenarios which had been scattered throughout it. For a time it was a bit of a chore to go through. Thankfully, the skip button helps you rush through the things you have already read, cutting out unnecessary game-time. You definitely need to be patient when going through Hatoful Boyfriend. I personally feel that in order to get the most enjoyment out of it you should go through one route at a time. That way you will have plenty of time to reflect on what happened as well as keep your interest in the plot fresh.  PROS:  > Overall, Hatoful Boyfriend is short and sweet. A basic route can be finished in an hour even if you are a slow reader. This makes it a great thing to play before going to bed or when you just need to kill some time for a while.  > The art is soft, and the scenery colorful, making the backdrops pleasant. It is simple, but is still able to add to the mood.  > While many of the characters and their stories are tried-and-true they are still ones you can get attached to (for the most part, anyway).  > There is more than one unlockable route.  > The story becomes more advanced as you progress through the game.  CONS:  > The protagonist is simple and impressionable.  > During the main routes you do not get a lot of route-exclusive content. A lot of the scenarios are the ones you go through during the main story, so you end up having to read through much of what you already have.  > The running gags get old fast.  > You are unable to save at decision screens and must do so just before you are about to make a choice.  > There are very few CGs.  > Sometimes your saves will bring you to a backdrop and you cannot do anything at all so you have to exit and re-open the game (save your game in multiple slots just in case!).  All in all, I think that Hatoful Boyfriend is enjoyable. I feel that it rewards you well for your diligence. The final, true story that is Hatoful Boyfriend is great. I absolutely love the BBL ending, and think that it was worth all the time I spent working to get it. I believe that it is a fairly solid purchase.

The game is pretty entertaining because the writing is good and the idea of dating pigeons is funny. The characters are great, all with distinct personalities, including the main character. Unlike some other dating sims, it doesn't branch off into a separate route for each character you date --instead, the new stuff for each character is interspersed between scenes common to each character... expect to be hitting the skip button a lot. The amount of new content for each character is pretty good, though.  The real meat of the game is when you unlock the final route after completing all the other routes. To put this in perspective, there are 15 endings (not counting an epilogue). I read all of the dialogue out loud with my friend, using the skip button for dialogue we already saw before. It took 10 hours to do the 14 normal routes and 6 hours to do the final route alone-- that's how big the difference is. So make sure you do the final route, since it's a huge amount of the game and it really ties everything together well.  Where the game fell short for me was in the implementation. There were a number of annoying technical aspects that really detracted from the game. One was the skip button, which sometimes failed to skip past old dialogue and would also skip past new dialogue. Another big one was the save games, which do not work if you have the game installed somewhere other than your C drive-- a real annoyance with the really long final route. And then there were just some small annoyances like unnecessary extra clicks (such as having to click twice before every choice), the slow speed of the scene transitions, and a ton of typos... which were actually kind of entertaining, but still.  Even so, the game is worth playing. It might not be the most polished VN you'll ever play, but it has some solid writing and is just a really fun experience.

A dating Sim with birds? Pah, that's ridiculous!... is what you are probably thinking. And you are right, but that is not the whole truth; beneath its satirical surface, Hatoful Boyfriend hides a gripping story that turns it into a very solid Visual Novel.  + The silly humour makes this VN accessible even to those who are not into Japanese culture, making it excellent (and affordable) for those seeking to dip into the genre; + While short, the main routes are solid and varied, ranging from tear-jerkers to plain WTF, with some hilarity in between (try Okosan's route first of all!) + The 'hidden' (and arguably 'canon') route presents a very interesting darker tale; + The OST and visuals are not mind-blowing, but they are pleasant and do their job.   +- While I did say it was a fine VN for beginners, it is still a parody of the dating sim genre and thus some of its content might fly over your head; +- The ending of the 'hidden' route might be considered too convoluted by some, although I would say the journey is still worth it, no matter what opinion you might have of the ending.  - While the main routes being a bit on the short side isn't a big deal and not something I can complain too much about considering the game's price, I do think some routes could've been fleshed out a little more; - The translation has some typos and English oddities.  VERDICT: If you think that this game is just a gimmick, play it and let yourself be surprised! With more than what meets the eye (you can easily clock 6-8h if you complete all routes), Hatoful Boyfriend was an excellent surprise and should be considered by all those who enjoy Visual Novels or plot-heavy games. If you are looking for gameplay-heavy elements, however, you WILL be disappointed, but that's just how VNs are.

Hatoful Boyfriend isn't just the hilarious pigeon dating sim you see on the surface. Radical political parties, genocide, experimentation, biological warfare, murder, pudding--just to name a few--are all themes you'll encounter in this game.  You are a human transfer student in a school specifically for birds. Unbeknownst to you, your mission is to woo every bird in the school, albeit one at a time in separate playthroughs. Each bird has different interests, personalities, and backstories, but the more you play, the more you'll realize that they're all intertwined, and that there's something terribly sinister going on at your school behind the scenes. Once you've seduced every bird and achieved every ending, you are rewarded with a chance to 'fulfill the promise,' and solve a mystery that will leave you on the edge of your seat for hours.  Hatoful Boyfriend is beyond deceptive in its marketing as a joke, and I hadn't expected that it would tell a wonderfully written story that would leave me in tears at its end.  --  My only gripe about Hatoful Boyfriend is the spotty save system, as so many others seem to have issues with, too. I would occasionally need to load a save only to find that it would load a background without characters, text, or interface, forcing me to Alt+F4 to leave the game. The save file was forever corrupted, and I would have to restart that particular storyline. The dating playthroughs are short enough to finish in single sittings, but the finale can take hours to finish. I would recommend playing the finale only if you know you have a lot of free time ahead of you, at least until the save issues are fixed. I will amend this review should they be resolved.  Oh, and the occasional typo or missing word, but that's not a big deal.  --  Have fun, everybirdie!

Hatoful Boyfriend takes a fun one-note gag of dating birds and executes it flawlessly, then executes half a dozen other things flawlessly while it's at it. It constantly mixes up its approach, and the result is a story that manages to be hilarious, goofy as all hell, but also legitimately touching.  Ultimately, playing Hatoful is something of a question of sincerity. Yes, the world and story are totally bananas. But the game's willingness to change tone on a dime and play things completely straight leads to no small number of poignant moments. The world of St. Pigeonation's is absurd, but is it really any more absurd than the latest tale of heroic space marines, robo-Nazis, or godlike gangsters? Not really, and at some point, after dealing with characters that act, talk, hope, and fear just like people, you're going to stop caring that their portrait is a ridiculous looking bird. And then, just when you start to get a little emotional, it's going to hit you in the face with another pie.  If there's a downside, it's that the actual gameplay can get a little tedious. A huge chunk of the game doesn't open up until you've romanced all of the birds, and a few of the birds have 'normal' vs. 'perfect' endings that make for two near-identical playthroughs. So after a few times through, you'll want to pull up a guide (and thankfully there are some good ones) and make judicious use of the fast-forward button to breeze through repeat content. I promise it's worth it, though.

Hatoful boyfriend is one of my favorite games to date.   WARNING - SERIOUS SPOILERS AHEAD  On a surface level, this is like any other Japanese dating sim - except with pigeons. As Pigeonations High School's only human student, Hiyoko Tosaka, you have the option of romancing a number of birds, each with their own unique personality and backstory, and can even unlock secret birds. Most dating scenarios end with a surprisingly heavy twist, even if you achieve the 'good ending'. The atmosphere of the dating scenarios is very bright and pleasant for the most part. The humour, and there's a lot of it (some possibly unintentional and resulting from the translation), adds a lot to the game.   SPOILER WARNING AGAIN  But the dating scenarios are just a facade. The true game is unlocked by achieving the good ending for a few certain birds. Once you have unlocked it, you find yourself in a post-apocalyptic, dystopian world wherein the majority of the human race succumbed to the avian flu. As a result of experiments conducted on birds to combat the virus, birds have gained sentience and human-like characteristics and intelligence, and now rule the earth. Hiyoko, the human protagonist, is gruesomely murdered, and all Pigeonations students are under lockdown. Playing as Ryouta, your duty is to discover the disturbing circumstances of Hiyoko's death, and reveal the true nature of Operation Hatoful.

Normally I'm not a fan of love stories. I often find them boring and in most cases predictable. Still I tried some Otome games out, because I was curious. In the end I just got confirmed what I thought beforehand: Dating Sims, wether they're for girls or boys, are pubertal immature sex/romantical fantasies which feature stupid stories and stereotypical/sexist/sexualised characters.  I despise this genre of video games.  But then I heard of Hatoful Boyfriend and that it would be a parody on this genre. That got me interested and I bought it.  And I absolutely don't regret it!  You're going to a school, can choose a route with a specific character you like and fall in love with him. Due to that you can get different endings. If you want to see all endings you have to play it several times. The basics are absolutely the same as in other Dating Sims.  But the differences are awesome!  Let's begin with the protagonist: She's not a weak, whining little girl like in most other games, but actually likeable and funny- due to the game having a satirical undertone. I just couldn't stand the protagonists which I've met in other games, they were extremely annoying.  I think it's definitely doing justice to it's reputation of being a parody. It's poking fun at rpg games, at PETA, at generic anime situations and also at stupid gender roles.  Dialogues are on the one hand very funny and hilarious, but on the other much less stiff than in other games, but in certain occasions even very serious or sad.  While in other games characters are often superficially done, here the characters are lovely and have a well-thought-out background.  The story or rather stories (because of all the different characters) are well done! What I like about them is, that they make much more sense than in other games and are even logically. In other Dating Sims they're just stupidly predictable. But the endings here surprised me.  Then there's also this special route, which you can unlock if you have a specific number of endings. This special story answers the questions, that many had already in their head when they heard of this game the first time: Why birds?  I loved this route and how every other piece of story the player gathered while doing the other routes came together to one and explained everything that's going on there.  By the way: If you want to have every ending then you have to play the game several times. There's this nice fast forward button with which you can skip everything that you already know. Otherwise it would've been a bit frustrating, but fortunately that's not the case.  Hatoful Boyfriend also showed that game developers shouldn't be afraid to do something with the fate of the protagonist...   While other game developers do everything so that the protagonists doesn't die and can be the glorious hero in the end, here it is possible that you get an ending were you die.    To put it in a nutshell: I love this game. The characters, the story and the dialogues are awesome. And while it has a lot of funny moments, it has also some very serious, sad and deep moments. Don't be fooled by their appearance, those pigeons are much more human than you think.
